State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 PR China With the rapid acceleration of industrialization, the emission of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon monoxide (CO) has emerged as a pressing global environmental issue, posing significant threats to ecosystems and human health. Copper-based catalysts have garnered substantial attention in the field of multi-pollutant synergistic treatment due to their abundant availability, low cost, and superior catalytic performance. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the recent advancements in copper-based catalysts for the removal of NOx and CO from flue gas, with a focus on their applications in selective catalytic reduction (SCR), CO catalytic oxidation, and bifunctional co-catalysis. Through an in-depth analysis of key factors influencing catalytic performance—such as valence modulation, morphological structure design, optimization of preparation methods, auxiliary doping, and adjustment of metal ratios—the critical roles of various catalyst properties are elucidated. These include redox capabilities, acidic nature, surface oxygen vacancy concentration, and active site dispersion in the catalytic process. Furthermore, this paper explores in detail the reaction mechanisms and sulfur-resistant properties of copper-based catalysts employed in several strategies for NOx and CO removal, highlighting the potential of bifunctional catalysts for simultaneous NOx and CO abatement. Significant progress has been achieved in enhancing low-temperature activity and stability through the optimization of preparation processes, intermetallic interactions, and structural design of copper-based catalysts. These advancements provide crucial theoretical insights and practical guidance for the development of future environmental treatment technologies, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable solutions to address global pollution challenges. With the acceleration of industrialization, the rapid expansion of the iron and steel industry has significantly increased the demand for fossil fuels, while simultaneously presenting more severe environmental challenges [1,2]. In the iron and steel production process, the sintering stage has emerged as a critical link in pollution control, primarily due to its emissions of atmospheric pollutants such as carbon monoxide (CO) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). These pollutants not only threaten ecological systems but also have profound implications for human health [3]. Among them, NOx serves as a key precursor to acid rain and photochemical smog, contributing to soil and water acidification, disrupting ecosystem balance, and causing respiratory and cardiovascular diseases in humans [4]. Meanwhile, CO, a colorless and odorless toxic gas, forms carboxyhemoglobin upon binding with hemoglobin in the human body, thereby weakening blood oxygen transport capacity and inducing tissue hypoxia. Severe exposure may even pose life-threatening risks [5]. Consequently, it is imperative to adopt efficient technological solutions to mitigate CO and NOx emissions, aligning with the goals of environmental protection and sustainable development [6–8]. For CO and NOx removal, different techniques exhibit distinct characteristics. For CO removal, the concentration of CO in real environments is typically lower than the range required for combustion methods, which is insufficient to support the complete combustion of CO under ordinary conditions [9]. In contrast, the catalytic oxidation method can facilitate reactions at lower CO concentrations. This method promotes the reaction of carbon monoxide with oxygen through the action of catalysts, thereby converting toxic carbon monoxide into carbon dioxide [10]. With advancements in catalyst technology, the catalytic oxidation method has achieved significant progress in improving conversion efficiency, reducing energy consumption, and broadening its scope of application. In terms of NOx removal, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) has become the most widely used technology in the industry, surpassing alternatives such as selective non-catalytic reduction (SNCR) and non-selective catalytic reduction (NSCR) due to its high catalytic efficiency and economic advantages [11]. The core principle of SCR is the reduction of NOx (primarily NO) to harmless N2 by catalytic action over a wide temperature range. Commonly used reductants in this process include NH3 and CO [12,13]. Ammonia (NH3) is often used as a reductant in the NH3-selective catalytic reduction of NO (NH3-SCR), which efficiently and selectively converts NOx to N2 and H2O at low temperatures [14]. The cost-effectiveness of ammonia is a primary reason for the widespread adoption of SCR technologies. It is widely accepted that NH3-SCR follows the reaction mechanisms outlined in equations (1-1) to (1-4) [15]. With the continuous improvement of environmental protection standards, single-pollutant control technologies have become inadequate for meeting the current needs of multi-pollutant synergistic management. Therefore, developing more efficient multi-pollutant joint control technologies is particularly important. Utilizing CO as a reductant in CO selective catalytic reduction of NO (CO-SCR) technology allows for the simultaneous removal of both CO and NOx pollutants produced during flue gas sintering, achieving the goal of "waste treatment using waste" [16]. This process typically adheres to the reaction equation (1-5): (1-1) 4 N H 3 + 6 NO → 5 N 2 + 6 H 2 O ( slow SCR ) (1-2) 4 N H 3 + O 2 + 4 NO + → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O ( standardSCR ) (1-3) 2 N H 3 + NO + N O 2 → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O ( fastSCR ) (1-4) 8 N H 3 + 6 N O 2 → 7 N 2 + 12 H 2 O ( N O 2 − SCR ) (1-5) 2 NO + 2 CO → N 2 + 2 C O 2 Although CO-SCR technology has achieved remarkable results in the synergistic treatment of multiple pollutants, significant challenges remain, particularly in treating high concentrations of CO. In actual flue gas environments, the presence of O2 causes CO to preferentially react with O2 to form CO2. This not only depletes the available CO in the flue gas but also significantly reduces NOx removal efficiency [17]. To address this challenge, Professor Chen Jianjun from Tsinghua University proposed an innovative concept: the development of a bifunctional catalyst capable of simultaneously facilitating both NH3-SCR and CO oxidation reactions on the same catalyst. The theoretical foundation of this approach lies in exploring the coupling mechanism between these two processes and optimizing NH3-SCR efficiency by utilizing the heat released during CO oxidation. Specifically, the heat generated from CO oxidation enhances temperature uniformity within the reaction system, thereby promoting efficient NH3-SCR operation across a broader temperature range. Furthermore, this synergistic effect reduces the system's reliance on external heating sources, significantly lowering overall energy consumption and operational costs [18]. NH3-SCR coupled with CO oxidation technology not only achieves high-efficiency removal of NOx and CO but also minimizes system energy consumption and operating expenses [19]. Thus, the study and development of bifunctional catalysts with excellent NH3-SCR performance and efficient CO oxidation capabilities hold great theoretical and practical significance for advancing scientific and technological progress in environmental management. In response to the increasingly severe air pollution problem, researchers have devoted significant effort to developing efficient pollutant control technologies, particularly in designing and optimizing catalysts capable of effectively removing NOx and CO. In this field, noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pt, Ir, Rh, Pd, etc.) are favored due to their exceptional catalytic activity and high selectivity in NH3-SCR, CO-SCR, and CO catalytic oxidation reactions [20–22]. However, despite their outstanding performance, these catalysts have inherent limitations that cannot be overlooked. For instance, at high temperatures, noble metal catalysts are prone to sintering, leading to the loss of active components and a consequent reduction in catalytic efficiency. Moreover, the scarcity and high cost of precious metals significantly hinder their widespread industrial application [23]. To overcome these challenges, researchers have increasingly focused on transition metal catalysts, which exhibit promising potential in catalytic cycles due to their flexible valence properties and ability to synergize with other metals. While commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts have been widely adopted in practical applications for NH3-SCR reactions, their limitations are evident. These include a narrow temperature window, insufficient catalytic activity at low temperatures, and the potential release of toxic substances (e.g., V2O5) at high temperatures, posing environmental and health risks [24]. Consequently, the search for alternative active components to replace vanadium-based catalysts has become a key research focus. In this context, various transition metal oxide systems have been proposed and extensively studied, including CeO2 [25,26], MnOx [27–29], Fe2O3 [30], CuO [31,32] among others. These materials are not only abundant and cost-effective but also typically exhibit high catalytic activity and good stability, making them highly promising candidates for future applications. Copper is a typical three-dimensional electron-type transition metal that combines unique physical and chemical properties, making it highly advantageous in various catalytic reactions. In particular, copper-based catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their exceptional performance in NH3-SCR, CO-SCR, and CO catalytic oxidation processes. From a resource perspective, copper is abundant, cost-effective, and readily available in nature, laying the foundation for its large-scale industrial application [33]. Additionally, copper exhibits versatile oxidation states (Cu0, Cu(I), and Cu (II)), which endow copper-based catalysts with diverse pollutant removal capabilities under varying reaction conditions. Their catalytic activity primarily stems from single-electron transfer processes (Cu2+ ↔ Cu1+, Cu1+ ↔ Cu0) or double-electron transfer processes (Cu2+ ↔ Cu0), enabling them to participate in complex redox reactions with high efficiency [34]. Furthermore, copper oxides exist in two stable forms—CuO and Cu2O. These oxides are not only structurally robust but also allow precise control over morphology and structure through modulation of synthesis conditions. This control optimizes the surface properties of the catalysts and enhances the distribution of reactive sites, significantly improving catalytic efficiency [35]. Consequently, copper-based catalysts are considered a vital research direction in the field of synergistic multi-pollutant management due to their excellent performance and economic feasibility. Despite their numerous advantages, copper-based catalysts face challenges in practical applications. Researchers have explored strategies to improve low-temperature activity, enhance N2 selectivity, and broaden the reaction temperature window. While numerous review articles summarize and discuss research findings on copper-based catalysts in SCR technology and CO catalytic oxidation, systematic studies on their performance and mechanisms in the synergistic reduction of NOx and CO catalytic oxidation remain scarce [36]. Thus, an in-depth investigation into the potential mechanisms and optimization strategies of copper-based catalysts in this context is not only a current research focus but also a critical step toward advancing the technology. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the research progress of copper-based catalysts in NOx selective catalytic reduction (SCR), CO catalytic oxidation, and the coupled with interaction between NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation. By analyzing the mechanisms of individual catalytic reactions and discussing the interactions among reactions during coupled with catalysis, this paper elucidates key factors influencing reaction performance. Addressing the limitations of current copper-based catalysts, the paper highlights strategies to enhance their catalytic performance, such as optimizing preparation processes, introducing additives, modulating the valence state of copper species, and adjusting the structural morphology of the catalysts. Specifically, these improvements aim to enhance the catalysts' redox capacity, regulate their acidic properties, increase the number of surface oxygen vacancies, and optimize the spatial distribution of active sites. These efforts contribute to the design of new copper-based catalysts with wider temperature windows, higher catalytic activity, and superior stability. Moreover, this paper underscores the future potential of copper-based catalysts, offering theoretical guidance and practical references for subsequent research. This work aims to promote further development and refinement of the technology in this field, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable environmental solutions. 2 NH3-SCR reaction 2.1 Reaction mechanism An in-depth understanding of the reaction mechanisms and pathways of NOx over catalysts is crucial for guiding the design of catalysts for NH3-SCR reactions. These reactions follow different pathways depending on the catalyst system, which is influenced by variations in acidic properties, redox capacities, and the resulting active intermediates. To date, two primary mechanisms for the NH3-SCR reaction have been widely recognized: the Eley-Rideal (E-R) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanisms, as illustrated in Fig. 1 [37]. The E-R mechanism is a single adsorption process in which NH3, in the adsorbed state, reacts with gaseous NO. The specific reaction process is as follows [38]: (2-1) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( ads ) (2-2) M ( n − 1 ) + + O → M n + = O (2-3) M n + = O + N H 3 ( ads ) → − N H 2 ( ad ) + M ( n − 1 ) + − OH (2-4) M n + = O + − N H 2 ( ad ) → NH ( ad ) + M ( n − 1 ) + − OH (2-5) NO ( g ) + − N H 2 ( ad ) → N 2 + H 2 O (2-6) NO ( g ) + M n + − O + NH ( ad ) → N 2 O + M ( n − 1 ) + − OH (2-7) M ( n − 1 ) + − OH + 1 / 4 O 2 ( g ) → M n + = O + 1 / 2 H 2 O (2-8) NO ( g ) + − − N H 2 → N H 2 NO → N 2 + H 2 O where, M denotes the metal active center on the catalyst surface, while n represents the oxidation state or charge number of the metal M. In the L-H mechanism, NO is first adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, where it becomes activated into nitro species. Subsequently, it reacts with NH3 in its adsorbed state, representing a double adsorption mechanism. During this process, NH3 dehydrogenation directly reacts with adsorbed NO, as described by Equations (2-9) - (2-12). Meanwhile, NO can also be oxidized by high-valence redox sites on the catalyst surface to produce NO2 or nitrite/nitrate species, following the reaction pathways outlined in Equations (2-13) - (2-16). [42] found that CuO/PRM catalysts follow the E-R mechanism during the NH3-SCR reaction. In this mechanism, highly dispersed CuO enhances the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface, promoting the adsorption and activation of NH3, while simultaneously weakening the adsorption capacity of NOx. This facilitates the desorption of NOx from the catalyst surface, thereby providing more active sites for NH3 adsorption. Wang et al. [43] suggested that the abundance of Lewis acid sites, large specific surface area and pore volume, as well as the synergistic effect between Cu+ and Cu2+, collectively promote the performance of CuO/Cu2O heterostructured catalysts in NH3-SCR via the E-R mechanism (Fig. 2a). Li et al. [44] concluded that Cu-modified TiO2/CeO2 catalysts primarily perform NH3-SCR through the E-R mechanism, where pre-adsorbed NH3 reacts with gaseous NOx to form N2 and H2O. Interestingly, the reaction mechanism shifts with temperature changes, as illustrated in Fig. 2b. At 180 °C, the NH3-SCR reactions of Cu2O, Cu2O-CuO, and CuO particles follow the L-H mechanism. However, as the temperature increases to 240 °C, the Cu2O catalyst switches to the E-R mechanism, where internal hydrogen transfer becomes the rate-limiting step. For CuO catalysts, the L-H mechanism dominates, with atomic isomerization being the rate-determining step. Meanwhile, Cu2O-CuO exhibits characteristics of both L-H and E-R mechanisms [45]. Despite these findings, many researchers believe that both reaction mechanisms can coexist in the same catalyst system to enhance reaction performance. Wang et al. [46] discovered that Mo-doped CuO catalysts exhibit excellent low-temperature activity. Specifically, the generated NO2 rapidly reacts with liganded NH3 adsorbed species via the E-R mechanism, while nitrite and nitrate adsorbed species react with NH4 +, liganded NH3, and NH2 adsorbed species via the L-H mechanism. Chen et al. [47] proposed that the SCR reaction of CuO/TiO2 catalysts follows both the L-H and E-R mechanisms. In this case, L-NH3, B-NH4 +, and –NH2 species can react with gaseous NO to produce N2 and H2O, whereas the reaction of N-H species with NO generates N2O and H2O. Additionally, the reaction between adsorbed NH3 species and pre-adsorbed NO species proceeds via the L-H mechanism, where nitrate species (NO3 −) react with L-NH3 and –NH2 to form N2 and H2O. Furthermore, the reaction of NO3 − with B-NH4 + produces NH4NO3, which subsequently decomposes into N2O and H2O. 2.2 Effecting factors of catalytic performance As a common metal oxide, CuO has garnered significant interest due to its abundant raw materials and low cost. Moreover, CuO exhibits variable valence states, enabling it to provide excellent redox activity in NH3-SCR reactions. Despite these advantages, pure CuO catalysts suffer from a relatively narrow temperature window and demonstrate good catalytic performance only at low temperatures. To address these limitations, recent research has focused on modifying pure CuO by incorporating a second metal, optimizing preparation methods, and appropriately modulating the valence state of copper species. These strategies have emerged as key areas of investigation in the field. 2.2.1 Effect of preparation methods The preparation method plays a critical role in determining the phase composition, conformation, and dispersion of the active component. Optimizing the preparation method can lead to highly dispersed active components and an increased specific surface area, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. For CuO-supported catalysts, the active CuO phase is prone to sintering and aggregation at high temperatures, which results in a decrease in SCR activity. Therefore, it is essential to identify suitable preparation methods to optimize the SCR performance of these catalysts. Nie et al. [48] prepared Cu-Ti-CO3 layered double hydroxides (LDHs) via co-precipitation and synthesized CuyTi1Ox catalysts using these LDHs as precursors. Benefiting from the highly dispersed active CuO phase, abundant surface acidic sites, and enhanced redox properties, the optimal CuyTi1Ox catalyst achieved 88.9% NOx conversion at 200 °C. This performance surpassed that of a 10 wt% CuO/TiO2 catalyst prepared by the conventional wet impregnation method. Additionally, the CuyTi1Ox catalyst exhibited good tolerance to SO2. Yan et al. [49] prepared AMO-Cu-Al-CO3 layered double hydroxides (LDHs) using the co-precipitation method and synthesized Cu4AlOx catalysts from these LDH precursors. This approach enables fine-tuning of the active metal's dispersion at the atomic level. As shown in the Fig. 3 , the Cu4AlOx catalyst derived from the AMO-Cu-Al-CO3 LDH precursor demonstrated excellent catalytic activity and resistance to deactivation in the NH3-SCR reaction. This was attributed to the high dispersion of the CuO active species and the abundance of acidic sites. The catalyst achieved up to 91.1% NOx conversion at 200 °C, significantly outperforming the 81.8% conversion rate of a 10 wt.% CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared via conventional wet impregnation. Similarly, a CuyMnzAl(1-z)Ox catalyst derived from a hydrotalcite precursor [50], also exhibited outstanding performance in the NH3-SCR reaction due to its high specific surface area, strong reducibility of MnO2 and CuO, abundant surface acid sites, and excellent dispersion of the active components. Notably, the best-performing catalyst, Cu2Mn0.5Al0.5Ox, achieved 91.2% NOx conversion at 150 °C. 2.2.2 Effects of the valence state of copper species The valence state of CuOx plays a crucial role in constructing high-performance Cu-based oxide catalysts for low-temperature SCR. Cu-based oxide catalysts exhibit excellent performance in the NH3-SCR reactions at low temperatures, and their activity is significantly influenced by the valence state of Cu [45]. Chen et al. [51] demonstrated that CuO-CeO2-TiO2 catalysts displayed exceptional NOx reduction activity within the temperature range of 150–250 °C. This superior performance was primarily attributed to highly dispersed Cu2+-generated Lewis acid sites, which serve as key active sites for the low-temperature activation/oxidation of NH3 and NOx. Consequently, Cu2+ is considered the primary active site. However, Qi et al. [42] argued that Cu+ species play a more critical role in the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. They demonstrated that in CuO/PRM catalysts with an appropriate CuO content, highly dispersed Cu species can effectively promote redox reactions, generating catalytically active Cu+ species and surface oxygen species (Cu2+ + Fe2+ ↔ Cu+ + Fe3+). This process not only significantly increases the number of Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface but also enhances the overall reduction performance of the catalyst. Consequently, these factors substantially improve the NH3-SCR reaction activity of the catalyst. Peng et al. [52] regulated the valency of Cu by adjusting the calcination temperature, while Wang et al. [30] synthesized CuO/Cu2O heterostructures and pure-phase CuO and Cu2O by altering the coordination environment of Cu. Wu et al. [53] prepared highly dispersed and valency-tunable CuOx species using a CuAl-LDH precursor for controlled carbothermal reduction reactions. These studies collectively agreed that the outstanding denitrification performance was mainly due to the synergistic effect between Cu2+ and Cu+. This finding was further corroborated by Li et al. [45], who observed that the Cu2O-CuO heterojunction achieved 83% NOx conversion at 240 °C, largely attributed to the synergistic interaction between Cu2+ and Cu+. Specifically, Cu2+ facilitates the formation of monodentate nitrate species and enhances the activation and dehydrogenation of NH3, leading to high catalytic activity in CuO. In contrast, Cu+ promotes the formation of bidentate nitrate species as well as the adsorption of NH3 and NOx, thereby improving N2 selectivity. The synergistic interaction between Cu2+ and Cu+ not only boosts redox capacity but also enhances the formation of adsorbed oxygen species on the catalyst surface, further facilitating the reaction process. 2.2.3 Effect of auxiliary modification The addition or loading of a second metal (e.g., Mo, Nb, Ce, etc.) enables the formation of composite metal oxides, which significantly enhances the NH3-SCR reaction performance of CuO-based catalysts. This improvement typically manifests in increased catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. Chen et al. [51] investigated the use of CuO-CeO2-TiO2 catalysts for the NH3-SCR reaction. Compared to CuTi catalysts, doping with CeO2 lowered the reduction temperature and enhanced the reducibility of CuO, thereby promoting the NH3-SCR reaction at low temperatures. The strong interaction between copper, cerium, and titanium oxides resulted in high dispersion of the metal oxides, leading to higher mobility of adsorbed oxygen species. This improved the acidity of the catalyst and facilitated the adsorption of reactants and the overall reaction process. The low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction on CuO-CeO2-TiO2 ternary oxides primarily proceeded via the "fast SCR" reaction pathway. In this pathway, Cu2+-NO species, nitrates coordinated to cerium sites, and ammonia coordinated to titanium sites interacted efficiently, as described by Xing et al. [54]. Ce doping substantially altered the surface properties of CuO composite oxides, particularly the distribution of Cu+. By adjusting the Ce/Cu molar ratio, the distribution of Cu+ could be optimized, thereby enhancing the redox properties and acidic characteristics of the catalyst. Notably, at a Ce/Cu molar ratio of 0.25, the catalyst (CeOx)0.25CuO exhibited the best catalytic performance, achieving nearly 100% NO conversion and excellent SO2 resistance within the temperature range of 250–350 °C. Wang et al. [46] reported that a novel Mo-doped CuO catalyst achieved more than 80% NOx conversion at 175 °C. The incorporation of Mo facilitated the formation of Cu-O-Mo species, enhancing electronic interactions between Cu and Mo. This not only increased the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface, thereby improving the adsorption capacity of NH3 and NOx, but also significantly diversified the types of chemisorbed oxygen species. These effects promoted the oxidation process from NO to NO2 and enhanced low-temperature reaction activity via the "Fast-SCR" pathway. Sher Ali et al. [55] explored the effect of the Cu/Nb ratio on catalyst activity and found that the introduction of Nb enhances both acidic sites and NOx adsorption sites. The Cu0.25-Nb0.85 catalyst exhibited complete NO conversion and near 100% N2 selectivity over a wide temperature range of 180–330°C. The addition of Nb also improved the redox properties of the catalysts, enhancing their catalytic activity through the following reaction: Cu2+ + Nb4+ ↔ Cu+ + Nb5+. 2.2.4 Effect of morphological structure The performance of copper-based catalysts in the NH3-SCR reaction is closely linked to the structure and dispersion of their copper oxide species, which are significantly influenced by the type and morphology of the carrier [56–59]. Yao et al. [60] prepared CuO/Ti0.95Ce0.05O2 catalysts and compared them with CuO/TiO2 and CuO/CeO2. Their results demonstrated that Ce4+ doping induced lattice distortion in TiO2, inhibited grain growth, and increased the specific surface area, thereby providing more active sites. Furthermore, the introduction of Ce4+ destabilized the coordination environment of Cu2+ in the catalyst, promoting a dual redox cycle (Cu2+ + Ce3+ ↔ Cu+ + Ce4+ and Cu2+ + Ti3+ ↔ Cu+ + Ti4+). This synergistic effect facilitated the formation of additional Lewis acidic sites, enhancing the activation of reactant molecules and producing more NH4NO2 species, which significantly improved the catalytic performance of the NH3-SCR reaction. Similarly, Si et al. [57] investigated CuOx/WOx-ZrO2 catalysts with varying Cu loadings and found that the 10 wt.% CuOx/WOx-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited optimal low-temperature NH3-SCR activity, achieving over 80% NO conversion in the range of 200–320 °C. The formation of the WOx-ZrO2 solid solution and the incorporation of copper oxide optimized the number and strength of Brønsted (B-) and Lewis (L-) acid centers, thereby enhancing catalyst performance. Specifically, at low temperatures (<200 °C), the NH3-SCR reaction primarily proceeded via the "NH3-NO2 route," where NO is first oxidized to NO2 and subsequently reduced by NH3. At higher temperatures (>250 °C), the reaction predominantly followed the "amine-NO/NO2 route," wherein amine species formed through NH3 adsorption at Lewis acid sites reacted with NO and NO2 to produce N2 (Fig. 4a). Wang et al. [61] highlighted that the crystallization temperature of TiO2 significantly affects its structure and morphology, which in turn influences the structure, morphology, and crystallization temperature of Cu/TiO2, ultimately impacting its catalytic properties. TiO2 nanorods synthesized at 160 °C exhibited the largest specific surface area, which was conducive to the high dispersion of active components and improved the catalyst's adsorption capacity. Additionally, the strong interaction between Cu species and TiO2 carriers affected the nature and quantity of surface oxygen species, optimizing the adsorption and activation of NO. The morphology of a catalyst plays a significant role in determining its catalytic performance. Zhuang et al. [62] synthesized Cu-Ce/TiO2 catalysts with varying morphologies, such as core-shell structures and nanotubes, using different preparation methods. Their findings demonstrated that these distinct preparation techniques influenced the specific surface area and pore structure of the catalysts. These structural differences, in turn, affected the adsorption and diffusion properties of reactants, thereby impacting the overall catalytic activity (Fig. 4b). 2.2.5 Summary of influencing factors In conclusion, several critical factors, including preparation methods, valence states of copper species, auxiliary doping, and catalyst morphology, play significant roles in determining the performance of copper-based catalysts in the NH3-SCR reaction. Catalysts derived from LDH precursors are particularly suited for low-temperature NH3-SCR applications due to their large specific surface area, high dispersion of active species, and abundant acidic sites. Nevertheless, these layered structures remain vulnerable to collapse during high-temperature calcination, presenting a key challenge for further enhancement. Future investigations should focus on designing LDHs that optimize both low-temperature activity and hydrothermal stability. Studies examining the influence of copper species' valence states have demonstrated that synergistic interactions between Cu+ and Cu2+ significantly boost catalytic efficiency. Specifically, Cu2+ facilitates the activation of NH3, while Cu+ enhances N2 selectivity. Further optimization of the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio, along with deeper exploration of this synergistic mechanism, could lead to the development of Cu-based catalysts offering higher conversion rates, improved N2 selectivity, and broader temperature operation windows. Research into co-agent modifications has shown that the interaction between CeO2 and CuO increases the number of surface acid sites, optimizing the adsorption and activation of NH3. Moreover, the Ce3+/Ce4+ cycle markedly improves the catalysts' low-temperature redox properties, promotes the Cu2+/Cu+ valence transition, and accelerates NO oxidation to NO2, thereby facilitating the fast SCR mechanism. Consequently, CeO2 stands out as the most promising additive for enhancing the performance of Cu-based catalysts at low temperatures. Additionally, incorporating additives to reduce the crystallinity of supports such as TiO2, and refining preparation techniques to produce carriers and catalysts (e.g., nanorods) with large specific surface areas, can help expose more active sites and achieve high dispersion of active components. These strategies collectively contribute to an overall enhancement in catalytic performance. 3 CO catalytic oxidation reaction 3.1 Reaction mechanism CO oxidation is a quintessential catalytic reaction, plays a crucial role in both energy and environmental applications. The reaction typically follows three main mechanisms: L-H [63], E-R [64]. and Mars-Van Krevelen(MvK) [65]. As illustrated in the Fig. 5 , the L-H mechanism involves the co-adsorption of both CO and O2 on the catalyst surface. O2 dissociates into reactive oxygen atoms, which then bind with the adsorbed CO, resulting in the formation of CO2, followed by desorption. The L-H mechanism is predominantly observed in noble metal catalysts [66,67]. In contrast, the E-R mechanism involves the adsorption of only one reactant (typically O2) on the catalyst surface, forming an active oxygen species. The other reactant (CO) then directly interacts with the adsorbed oxygen in its gaseous state, yielding CO2. This mechanism is particularly relevant for catalysts with highly activated surface oxygen species. The MvK mechanism, on the other hand, relies on the cycling of lattice oxygen. In this case, CO reacts with the catalyst's lattice oxygen to form CO2, creating oxygen vacancies, which are subsequently replenished by O2 from the gas phase. This mechanism is common in metal oxide catalysts, where the mobility of lattice oxygen plays a key role. Kasmi et al. [63] successfully synthesized Cu thin films using a gas-phase deposition technique and proposed a reasonable prediction for the reaction mechanism underlying CO oxidation over Cu thin-film catalysts. Their results demonstrated good correlation between simulation and experimental data when the reaction follows the L-H mechanism. Qian et al. [69] proposed a reaction mechanism, as shown in Fig. 6a, for 5Cu20TZ catalysts. In this system, Cu+ species play a crucial role in CO adsorption at low temperatures, while O2 preferentially occupies the surface active sites, thereby inhibiting CO adsorption. As the temperature increases, Cu+ species are reduced to Cu0, and the adsorbed CO molecules react with O2 species to form CO2, facilitating the complete oxidation of CO. This process aligns with the L-H mechanism. Khan et al. [70] studied CO oxidation over one-dimensional titanium dioxide nanorod (TNR)-loaded copper catalysts, where the reaction mechanism predominantly follows the L-H mechanism. Specifically, CO is chemisorbed at the active metal sites of the catalyst or at the metal-carrier interface, while O2 adsorbs onto the carrier surface. The adsorbed CO then reacts with O2 on the catalyst surface to form CO2, which desorbs. Ma et al. [71] investigated Fe-doped Cu/Al2O3 catalysts prepared via wet impregnation and found that Fe doping enhances the reduction capacity of CuO, leading to the formation of more oxygen vacancies, which serve as the primary active sites for CO oxidation. This process follows the MvK mechanism. Similarly, in studies of Cu-Ce-based catalysts (CuxO/CeO2), researchers observed that the carbonate-mediated MvK mechanism significantly enhances catalytic performance [72]. Fang et al. [73] reported that doping Ti atoms into CuO/TiO2-C catalysts led to the formation of a Ti-O-Cu heterostructure on the crystalline surfaces of CuO(111), where Cu atoms are replaced by Ti. As shown in Fig. 6b, this structure not only promotes the formation and stabilization of Cu+ species but also activates adjacent lattice oxygens. In this system, CO molecules are first adsorbed on Cu+ sites and subsequently react with the activated lattice oxygens to produce CO2 via the MvK mechanism. In some catalyst systems, two reaction mechanisms can operate simultaneously to enhance reaction performance. Shen et al. [74] showed that both the MvK and L-H mechanisms are active over CuCeOx catalysts in CO oxidation (Fig. 6c). In the MvK mechanism, CO is adsorbed on Cu+ sites and reacts with lattice oxygen to form CO2, with oxygen vacancies being replenished by gas-phase O2. In the L-H mechanism, a hydroxyl group serves as a reactive oxygen species, which reacts with the Cu+-CO species to form bicarbonate intermediates, which are readily decomposed to CO2. The combined action of both the E-R and MvK mechanisms contributes to the excellent CO oxidation performance of the CuO/α-MnO2 catalyst at low temperatures. In the E-R mechanism, the Cu+ site adsorbs CO, which then reacts with O2 to form CO2, with O2 remaining in the free state throughout the process, preventing competition between CO and O2 for adsorption. In the MvK mechanism, O2 is first adsorbed on the catalyst surface, filling oxygen vacancies to form lattice oxygen, which then reacts with CO to produce CO2 [75]. 3.2 Effecting factors of catalytic performance Copper-based catalysts have become a major focus of research due to their excellent low-temperature CO oxidation performance, demonstrating both high activity and stability in CO catalytic oxidation reactions [76]. The catalytic activity of copper-based catalysts is closely linked to their surface structure and the nature of their oxygen species. Non-stoichiometric, metastable copper oxides, in particular, exhibit higher activity in CO oxidation [77]. Additionally, factors such as the preparation method, reaction conditions, and morphology of copper-based catalysts significantly influence their catalytic performance [78]. These studies provide both theoretical and experimental insights that underpin the use of copper-based catalysts in CO oxidation, offering guidance for the development of more efficient and cost-effective CO abatement technologies. 3.2.1 Effect of preparation methods Preparation methods influence the catalytic activity of catalysts by altering their surface area and dispersion. Common preparation techniques include sol-gel [79,80], co-precipitation [81], impregnation [82,83]. and combustion [84–86], among others. Avgouropoulos et al. [85] compared the catalytic performance of CuO-CeO2 catalysts prepared by co-precipitation, citrate-hydrothermal, urea-nitrate combustion, and impregnation methods. The catalytic activity of the resulting catalysts was ranked as follows: combustion > citrate-hydrothermal > co-precipitation > impregnation. The superior catalytic activity of the first two methods is attributed to the presence of a large number of readily reducible and well-dispersed CuOx species, which strongly interact with the CeO2 surface. Shang et al. [87] also compared the catalytic performance of CuO/CeO2 catalysts prepared by impregnation, mechanical mixing, and co-precipitation methods. The results indicated that the impregnation method exhibited the highest catalytic performance, followed by co-precipitation, with the mechanical mixing method showing the poorest performance. The enhanced activity of the impregnation method is attributed to the strong interaction between highly dispersed CuO and CeO2, which promotes the reduction of CuO to Cu+ species at the Cu-Ce interface. In contrast, the lower activity observed with the co-precipitation method is due to the formation of a solid-solution structure that inhibits the Cu-Ce interface formation, resulting in the reaction of adsorbed CO with the active lattice oxygen. The mechanical mixing method is the least active, as it lacks a Cu-Ce interface due to the physical separation of CuO and CeO2 phases. CeO2 is often used as a support for CuO-based CO oxidation catalysts due to its excellent redox properties and outstanding oxygen storage and release capacity. However, the small specific surface area of CeO2 limits the further enhancement of its catalytic performance [88]. To overcome this limitation, strategies to increase its specific surface area are necessary to improve overall catalytic efficiency. Zhang et al. [89] employed a modified hydrothermal method to synthesize novel mesoporous CeO2 nanorods with a large specific surface area (Fig. 7a), which greatly facilitated the dispersion of the CuO active centers. These findings provide valuable insights for the preparation and application of CuO-CeO2 catalysts. For the impregnation method, Sun et al. [90] investigated the catalytic performance of CuO/CeO2 catalysts prepared by solid-phase impregnation (SSI) and wet impregnation (WI) methods. The results demonstrated that the catalysts prepared by the SSI method outperformed those prepared by the WI method. The enhanced performance of the SSI-prepared catalysts was attributed to improved dispersion of copper species on the catalyst surface and stronger interactions with cerium [91], which facilitated the reduction of CuO. Moreover, the superior catalytic activity was closely related to the higher concentration of oxygen vacancies on the carrier surface and a higher concentration of adsorbed CO on the Cu+ sites (Fig. 7b). The choice of solvent during the preparation process also significantly impacted the catalytic performance. Derekaya et al. [92] explored the effect of preparation method and solvent type on the catalytic activity of CuO-CeO2/Carbon catalysts using conventional impregnation and surfactant-assisted impregnation methods. In their experiments, solvents such as water, n-propanol, ethanol, acetone, and ethylene glycol were tested. The results showed that the catalyst prepared by surfactant-assisted impregnation with n-propanol as solvent had the best performance, achieving 50% CO conversion at 106 °C. This temperature was 54 ℃ lower than that of the catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method. The addition of the surfactant effectively enhanced the porosity and dispersion of the active components, thereby improving CO oxidation activity. Additionally, the distribution of active components could be tailored by controlling the evaporation rate of the solvent during drying. Sun et al. [93] similarly demonstrated that the addition of the surfactant CTBA improved the dispersion of CuO species and enhanced their synergistic interaction with CeO2, promoting the formation of a Cu-O-Ce solid solution. This led to the generation of more active lattice oxygen, further enhancing catalytic performance. In conclusion, different preparation methods significantly influence the dispersion of active components, their interaction with the carrier, and the overall catalytic performance of the catalysts. 3.2.2 Effects of the valence state of copper species The variable valence states of copper species play a crucial role in CO oxidation. Huang et al. [77] investigated the catalytic performance of copper oxide catalysts (Cu2O and CuO) in CO oxidation. The results showed that Cu2O exhibited the best catalytic activity, followed by the metastable CuO clusters, while CuO demonstrated the poorest performance. This difference was mainly attributed to the fact that the variable valence state of Cu2O facilitates the trapping and release of surface lattice oxygen, thus enhancing catalytic performance. Chen et al. [94] reported that Cu+ is more favorable for CO molecule adsorption compared to Cu2+, and that the synergistic effect of Cu+ and oxygen vacancies significantly impacts the catalytic oxidation process.Shi et al. [95] prepared a series of Cu2O-CuO heterojunction submicron cubic catalysts with tunable Cu2+/Cu+ ratios by precisely controlling the roasting temperature. The experimental results demonstrated that the heterojunction catalysts exhibited significantly better activity than the individual Cu2O and CuO catalysts. This superior activity was attributed to the synergistic effect of the heterojunction, which increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface and enhanced the activation of O2. As shown in Fig. 8a, in low-temperature CO oxidation, the lattice oxygen provided by CuO serves as a preferred adsorption site for CO molecules, and the generated oxygen vacancies are refilled by dissociated O atoms from Cu2O. The Cu2O-CuO heterojunction efficiently facilitates the reaction process, exhibiting excellent catalytic performance through the continuous generation and refilling of oxygen vacancies, as demonstrated by Liu et al. [96]. Different valence states and distributions of copper species significantly affect catalyst activity [98,99]. Zeng et al. [100] investigated the influence of copper species on the CO oxidation activity of CuOx/CeO2 catalysts. Their results showed that the roasting-treated CuOx/CeO2 catalyst contained both Cu+ and Cu2+ species. Among these, Cu+ was identified as the key active component responsible for CO molecule adsorption and activation. In contrast, Cu2+, primarily present as CuO, did not enhance catalyst activity, even when the copper oxide nanoparticles were reduced to monovalent copper to form oxygen vacancies. This finding indicated that, in CuOx/CeO2 catalysts, Cu+ serves as the active site for efficient CO oxidation, while the reduction of Cu2+ had no positive effect on catalytic activity. Du et al. [101] suggested that the surface Cu+ species, reduced from Cu2+, play a crucial role in catalyzing CO oxidation. The superior catalytic performance of copper-cerium oxide nanosheets was attributed to the highly dispersed CuOx clusters, rather than the Cu-[Ox]-Ce structure. The lower catalytic activity of clustered CuO in CO oxidation further supports this idea. Highly dispersed Cu species provide more active sites, thereby enhancing catalyst activity. The coexistence of Cu+ and Cu2+ promotes synergistic interactions with other elements and facilitates increased reaction efficiency. As shown in Fig. 8b, Li et al. [102] prepared CuO/Al2O3-CeO2 catalysts using hydrothermal and ultrasound-assisted impregnation methods. Their results demonstrated that the relative ratios of Cu+ to Cu2+ and their electronic synergistic interactions with the support significantly influenced catalytic activity. Compared to the CuO/Al2O3 catalyst, the introduction of CeO2 improved the dispersion of CuO on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the redox cycle of Ce3+ + Cu2+ ↔ Ce4+ + Cu+ facilitated the generation of oxygen vacancies. This synergistic effect not only enhanced oxygen migration but also optimized the low-temperature reduction performance of the catalyst. Furthermore, in situ DRIFTS analysis confirmed that the preferential adsorption of CO at Cu+ sites and the generation of reactive oxygen species were key mechanisms contributing to the catalyst's low-temperature activity. In conclusion, precise regulation of the valence and distribution of copper species can improve reaction performance by modulating active sites and controlling oxygen vacancy concentration. 3.2.3 Effect of morphological structure The morphology and exposed crystalline structure of copper species significantly affect the performance of CO-catalyzed oxidation [107]. Zhang et al. [103] investigated the impact of CuO structure on the catalytic CO oxidation reaction in CeO2-CuO/Cu2O catalysts. The study found that CeO2-CuO/c-Cu2O (cubic) nanocomposites exhibited lower activation energy at the CuO-CeO2 interface and a lower oxygen ion coordination of CuO/c-Cu2O. This led to higher catalytic activity compared to CeO2-CuO/o-Cu2O (octahedral) and CeO2-CuO/d-Cu2O (rhombic dodecahedral) nanocomposites (Fig. 9a). Antony et al. [104] attributed the differences in CO oxidation performance primarily to the morphology of CuO nanomaterials (NMs) and their associated interactions. They compared the performance of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with rice, needle, and flake shapes. Despite similar thermal stability, catalyst dispersion, porosity, specific surface area, and chemical properties, the acicular CuO NMs exhibited superior performance, demonstrating that morphology plays a crucial role in catalytic performance (Fig. 9b). In addition, the morphology of Cu2O crystals significantly influences their catalytic activity [108]. Jing et al. [109] investigated the performance of CeO2-CuO/Cu2O/Cu monolithic catalysts with Cu2O layers in rod-like, three-dimensional reticulated porous, and floral morphologies for preferential CO oxidation (CO-PROX). Catalysts with a flower-like morphology of Cu2O layers showed better activity at low temperatures, attributed to the highly dispersed CuO and high concentration of lattice oxygen. In contrast, catalysts with Cu2O layers exhibiting rod-like or reticulated morphologies showed higher activity at high temperatures, which was linked to larger CuO grain size and the strong synergistic effect of Cu-Ce interfacial sites. Interfacial electronic interactions and oxygen defects between CeO2 and Cu2O significantly affect CO oxidation activity. The CeO2/o-Cu2O (111) sample demonstrated high activity at low temperatures due to the presence of unsaturated copper surface atoms, which exhibited stronger interfacial electronic interactions than CeO2/c-Cu2O (100), resulting in more oxygen defects and enhanced oxidation, adsorption, and activation of CO and O2 reactants, thus improving catalytic performance [110]. Gao et al. [111] ompared the catalytic activity of Cu2O nano cubes (c-Cu2O) and nano-octahedra (o-Cu2O) in CO oxidation, focusing on the effect of catalyst morphology and crystal surface exposure on performance. The study found that c-Cu2O with exposed (100) crystal faces exhibited significantly higher activity in CO oxidation than o-Cu2O with exposed (111) crystal faces. This was attributed to the fact that the (100) surface of c-Cu2O is more easily oxidized to form a CuO surface layer during the reaction, whereas the (111) surface of o-Cu2O resists this surface oxidation. In contrast, Bao et al. [112] concluded that CuO/o-Cu2O is more active than CuO/c-Cu2O. Cu-based catalysts supported on various carriers are promising for CO oxidation reactions, with common carriers including CeO2 [113,114], TiO2 [115], Al2O3 [116], and SiO2 [117]. The morphology and exposed crystalline surface of these carriers influence their interaction with Cu species, the chemical state of the active components, and, consequently, the performance of CO catalytic oxidation [118]. Lykaki et al. [119] investigated the effect of morphology and the exposed crystalline surfaces of CeO2 on its structural defects and surface properties, identifying the following order of influence: nanorods > nanopolyhedra > nanocubes. This variation is attributed to the different exposed crystal faces (e.g., (110), (100), and (111)), which affect the formation of oxygen vacancies and surface defects. Among these, CeO2 nanorods exhibited the best CO oxidation activity, likely due to the exposure of their (100) and (110) crystal planes, which are associated with higher oxygen vacancy formation and stronger oxygen reduction ability.Gao et al. [105] demonstrated that, as shown in Fig. 9c, the structure of CuOx species and their interactions with CeO2 can be efficiently tuned by precisely adjusting the catalyst’s morphology and the exposure of its crystal planes, thereby optimizing catalytic performance in CO oxidation reactions. Chen et al. [120], in their study of nanosheet ZnO (p-ZnO) and nanorod ZnO (r-ZnO) catalysts loaded with 10% CuO, found that p-ZnO, with exposed (002) crystalline facets, had stronger interactions with CuO. These interactions facilitated the dispersion of CuO, promoted the formation of finer CuO nanoparticles, and generated more Cu(I) species during the reaction, which, in turn, formed oxygen vacancies on the ZnO surface. These factors enhanced both the intrinsic activity and stability of CuO/p-ZnO catalysts in CO oxidation. The presence of Cu(I) species and oxygen vacancies provided active sites for CO adsorption and O2 dissociation, which further boosted CO oxidation efficiency.The crystal type of the carrier also significantly influences CO catalytic oxidation performance. The dispersion of CuO and the exposure of active sites on the carrier determine the catalyst's oxidation performance [121]. For example, the activity of CuO/α-Fe2O3, which has more Cu+-CO species, is lower than that of CuO/γ-Fe2O3. This is because the surface of CuO/α-Fe2O3 tends to accumulate carbonate species, which cover the active sites and inhibit CO and O2 adsorption and activation. In contrast, CuO/γ-Fe2O3 produces minimal carbonate species, maintaining high activity. Furthermore, CuO/γ-Fe2O3 demonstrates better redox properties, promotes redox cycling between Fe2+/Fe3+, provides more reactive oxygen species, and is enriched with Fe2+ species and oxygen vacancies. These factors enhance oxygen activation, promoting CO oxidation in the critical rate-determining step (Fig. 9d) [106]. In summary, by controlling the phase morphology of CuO or the carrier, exposing crystal surfaces, and other methods, the oxygen vacancies and defects on the catalyst surface can be effectively modified. The valence state and distribution of Cu species at the active sites can also be regulated, thereby enhancing the redox capacity of the catalyst. These modifications have a crucial impact on the improvement of CO oxidation activity. 3.2.4 Summary of influencing factors In conclusion, optimizing the preparation method, modulating the valence state of Cu species, and adjusting the morphology and structure of catalysts are crucial for enhancing CO catalytic oxidation performance. Copper-based catalysts prepared using a surfactant-assisted impregnation method show significant potential in CO oxidation reactions. The addition of surfactants effectively regulates the pore structure of the catalysts and prevents agglomeration of active components, thereby achieving high dispersion of these components and promoting their interaction with other active phases. Among different valence states of copper species, Cu+ exhibits notable advantages in low-temperature CO oxidation. Cu+ not only adsorbs and activates CO molecules more efficiently but also provides more reactive oxygen through synergistic interactions with oxygen vacancies. Additionally, Cu+ forms beneficial synergies with other elements, significantly improving catalyst activity and reaction efficiency. However, the synergistic interaction between Cu2+ and Cu+ is equally important for enhancing the redox performance of the catalyst. Therefore, constructing Cu-based catalysts that predominantly contain Cu+ while moderately incorporating Cu2+ is ideal for achieving efficient CO oxidation. Building on this foundation, the construction of heterojunctions is considered a promising direction for further optimizing catalyst performance. Moreover, the impact of the diversity in morphology and exposed crystalline surfaces of both catalysts and supports on catalytic performance should not be overlooked. When designing CO oxidation catalysts, it is essential to consider comprehensively the dispersion of Cu active species, the increase of oxygen vacancies, and the enhancement of redox properties. Studies have shown that o-Cu2O with exposed (111) crystal faces promotes the formation of more oxygen defects due to its stronger interfacial electronic interactions. This characteristic provides additional active sites for CO and O2 adsorption and activation, accelerating the CO oxidation reaction. Consequently, when constructing CO oxidation catalysts, preference should be given to the o-Cu2O structure with exposed (111) crystal faces to fully exploit its catalytic advantages under low-temperature conditions. 4 Simultaneous removal of NOx and CO 4.1 CO-SCR reaction 4.1.1 Reaction mechanism Currently, the two widely recognized mechanisms for the CO-SCR reaction are the E-R mechanism and the L-H mechanism (Fig. 10 ) [123,124]. The L-H mechanism involves a reaction between adsorbates. In this process, NO is first adsorbed onto the active sites of the catalyst. As NO dissociates, the N–O bond breaks, forming adsorbed N and O atoms. The O atoms then react with CO molecules, also adsorbed on the catalyst surface, to form CO2, while two adjacent N atoms combine to form N2. The E-R mechanism, on the other hand, describes reactions between gaseous molecules and adsorbed species. In this case, NO is adsorbed on the catalyst surface, while CO remains in the gaseous form. The gaseous CO reacts directly with either the adsorbed NO or its dissociated species, leading to the formation of N2. This reaction ultimately produces products such as N2 and CO2. The CO-SCR reaction follows different mechanisms depending on the catalyst system. Dai et al. [125] found that for CoOx-CeO2 and FeOx-CeO2 catalysts, the Eley-Rideal mechanism predominates, with NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface reacting with gaseous CO. In contrast, the CuO-CeO2 catalyst is able to effectively adsorb CO due to the presence of Cu+ species, forming Cu+-CO characteristic species. During the CO-SCR reaction, these Cu+-CO species react with the NO species adsorbed on the CeO2 surface, following the L-H mechanism, resulting in N2 and CO2 formation. Han et al. [126] reported that the CO-SCR reaction over Cu-Mn-Ce modified coal-based activated carbon (AC) catalysts conforms to the L-H mechanism. As shown in Fig. 11a, NO is adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form NO* (adsorbed state), which dissociates to generate free radicals. These radicals then react with adsorbed CO to form N2 and CO2. At low temperatures, some undissociated NO reacts with CO to form N2O, which subsequently reacts with adsorbed CO to form N2 and CO2. Deng et al. [127] found that the reaction on the Cu/CeMn-10:1 catalyst also follows the L-H mechanism, where gaseous CO reacts with adsorbed NO (Fig. 11b). Bai et al. [128] concluded that the CO-SCR reaction on CuO/CeO2-Al2O3 follows the E-R mechanism. First, NO is adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form nitrate and nitrite. At low temperatures, gaseous CO reacts with the adsorbed NO species, leading to the formation of N2O. As the temperature increases, adsorbed NO species gradually decompose, and CO adsorbs on the released active sites. At higher temperatures, the adsorbed CO species react with gaseous NO, which favors the formation of N2 and enhances N2 selectivity. For some catalyst systems, multiple mechanisms can coexist, and the reaction mechanism for the same catalyst can change depending on the temperature. Pan et al. [129], in their study of metal-doped Fe2O3/rice husk ash (RHA) catalysts for low-temperature CO-SCR, found that at low temperatures, gaseous CO molecules reacted with dissociated radicals ([N], [O]) from the adsorbed NO species to produce CO2 and N2, following the E-R mechanism. At higher temperatures, adsorbed carbonate species reacted with adsorbed NO species at the Fe-Ox-Co active site, following the L-H mechanism (Fig. 11c). Tao et al. [130] demonstrated the best low-temperature activity and high-temperature stability through different anionic modifications of CoFe-LDH, specifically the NO3 -modified LDH loaded with 7.5% Cu (LDO(N)/Cu7.5). This catalyst exhibited different reaction mechanisms at varying temperatures. At 150°C and below, the catalyst primarily follows the E-R mechanism: NO is preferentially adsorbed and occupies part of the active sites, limiting CO adsorption. As the temperature increases, some of the adsorbed NOx reacts with gaseous CO to form N2O and CO2, while the remaining adsorbed NOx either desorbs or decomposes, freeing more active sites for CO adsorption. At 200 °C, a large number of Cu+-CO species and oxygen vacancies are generated on the catalyst surface, facilitating NO adsorption. This allows the adsorbed CO to react directly with NOx to form N2 and CO2, at which point the reaction follows the L-H mechanism (Fig. 11d). He et al. [17] similarly demonstrated that for the CuCe oxide catalyst in CO-SCR, the reaction follows the E-R mechanism at low temperatures (50–150 °C) and the L-H mechanism at high temperatures (200–400 °C). In actual industrial environments, the presence of O2 impacts the efficiency of the CO-SCR reaction. Under ideal conditions, the CO-SCR reaction is typically conducted in an oxygen-free environment or with O2 concentrations below half of the CO concentration, as such conditions minimally impact the reaction [131,132]. However, excessive O2 can change the mechanism of the CO-SCR reaction, significantly inhibits the selective reduction of NO by CO and degrades both NO conversion efficiency and N2 selectivity [132]. Chen et al. [133] investigated the catalytic CO-SCR reaction over CuCoOx/TiO2 catalysts and demonstrated that the introduction of O2 exerted a pronounced inhibitory effect. Their results revealed that NO conversion drastically declined from 98.9% to 56.2% when O2 concentrations increased from 2% to 10%. This inhibition arises from two mechanisms: first, O2 competes with CO for active sites on the catalyst surface, reducing CO adsorption and reaction efficiency; second, O2 promotes the oxidation of NO to NO2. Yamamoto et al. [134] elucidated the role of O2 in Cu/Al2O3 catalyst systems. They observed that even trace amounts of O2 (above 0.5%) drastically increased CO oxidation rates, leading to complete CO conversion. Simultaneously, elevated O2 concentrations reduced N2 production while increasing NO2 formation, indicating that CO preferentially reacts with O2 rather than NO. This preference for CO oxidation over CO-SCR under oxidizing conditions underscores the disruptive role of O2 in redirecting reaction pathways away from the desired NO reduction. In recent years, researchers have focused on developing catalysts that can maintain superior performance in high oxygen concentration environments. For instance, Ji et al. [135] constructed a Pt-CuO/CoAlO catalyst for the CO-SCR reaction by incorporating single-atom Pt. They observed that this catalyst achieved 100% NO conversion at 200 °C. Even with the introduction of 1% O2 into the system, the optimal catalytic performance remained unaffected. When 3% O2 was introduced into the catalytic system, the NO conversion efficiency of the optimal catalyst decreased but still maintained a relatively high level of 91%. In addition, the CO concentration significantly impacts the catalyst’s oxidation resistance. A moderate increase in CO concentration (equivalent to a reduction in the O2/CO ratio) can enhance NO reduction under constant O2 levels [136]. In conclusion, excessive O2 is detrimental to the CO-SCR process due to its dual role in competing for active sites and accelerating oxidative side reactions (e.g., CO oxidation and NO oxidation). Future research should prioritize strategies to mitigate O2’s inhibitory effects, such as optimizing catalyst designs with enhanced oxygen tolerance or employing in-situ O2 scavenging mechanisms. Such advancements would enable more efficient utilization of CO as a reducing agent, thereby fostering the practical implementation of "waste-to-waste" pollution control concepts in industrial applications. 4.1.2 Effecting factors of catalytic performance CO-SCR technology refers to the use of CO, rather than NH3, as a reductant to catalyze the reduction of NOx, thereby achieving the simultaneous removal of CO and NO from flue gas. This technology is considered a highly efficient and economical method for NOx emission reduction. The performance of CO-SCR is primarily influenced by factors such as the valence state of Cu, the type and number of oxygen vacancies in the catalysts, the dispersion of active species, and their redox properties. These factors can be optimized by adjusting the preparation methods, introducing additives, and regulating the catalyst morphology and structure to enhance the performance of CO-SCR. 4.1.2.1 Effect of preparation methods The preparation method significantly affects the dispersion of active species, redox capacity, and other factors that influence the catalyst's performance in CO-SCR reactions. Common preparation methods include co-precipitation [137,138], sol-gel [139], impregnation [140] and hydrothermal treatment [141,142]. Yao et al. [143] reported that CuO-CeO2 catalysts prepared by different methods, including mechanical mixing, impregnation, milling, hydrothermal treatment, and co-precipitation, exhibited varying catalytic activities. Among these, the CuO-CeO2 catalyst prepared by the impregnation method (CuCe-IM) showed the highest NO conversion and N2 selectivity. This was attributed to the highest concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, excellent reduction properties, and the largest amount of Cu+ species. The presence of Cu+ species promotes CO adsorption and activation, while the synergistic interaction between Cu+ species and oxygen vacancies facilitates the dissociation of adsorbed NO species. Co-impregnation and stepwise impregnation are common impregnation methods. The same study further explored the effect of these methods on catalytic performance by preparing two series of catalysts (xCuyMn/Ce and xCu/yMn/Ce) using co-impregnation and stepwise impregnation [140]. The results showed that the catalysts prepared by the co-impregnation method exhibited superior performance. This was attributed to better contact between the components, which enhanced interactions and significantly increased the reduction capacity of the catalysts. The stronger reduction performance promoted the formation of low-valent copper species (e.g., Cu+ and Cu0) and increased the number of surface oxygen vacancies (especially SSOVs), which favored CO adsorption and NO dissociation, thus improving overall catalytic efficiency. Sun et al. [144] also compared the two methods but reached different conclusions. They found that the stepwise impregnation method (CuCeAl-SI) effectively modulated the dispersion of copper species on the CeO2 surface, leading to the formation of more active sites at the CuO-CeO2 interface, which resulted in higher NO conversion and N2 selectivity. Different preparation methods can also influence the reaction mechanism. Bai et al. [145] used a combination of co-precipitation and impregnation methods to prepare Cu/Fe/Ce0.1Al and Cu/FeCe0.1Al catalysts. In the first case, both Cu and Fe were dispersed on the surface of the Ce0.1Al carrier, while in the second case, Cu was uniformly dispersed on the surface, and Fe was doped into the carrier’s interior. The researchers concluded that the dispersion states of Cu and Fe affected the active sites and reaction pathways. As shown in Fig. 12a, the Cu/Fe/Ce0.1Al catalysts followed the E-R mechanism, while the Cu/FeCe0.1Al catalysts predominantly followed the L-H mechanism. The grinding method offers several advantages, including ease of operation, environmental sustainability, and energy efficiency. When the appropriate grinding time is selected, it can effectively improve the reducibility and oxygen adsorption capacity of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its performance in the NO+CO reaction. Liu et al. [146] investigated the performance of Cu0.1La0.1Ce0.8O mixed-oxide catalysts prepared by the grinding method for the low-temperature CO-SCR. Their study revealed that the grinding time significantly affected the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of the catalysts. The results showed that the catalyst milled for 10 h (CLC 10h) exhibited the highest catalytic activity, good water resistance, and excellent catalytic stability. This was primarily attributed to the formation of Cu-O-Ce(La) active sites during the milling process, and the increased interaction between Cu and Ce(La) as the grinding time increased, which enhanced the generation of oxygen vacancies and the reactivity of adsorbed NOx species, thereby improving the redox performance of the catalyst. Due to their large specific surface area and good dispersion of metal species, the preparation of catalysts with excellent performance and high stability using hydrotalcite materials as precursors has become a research hotspot in recent years [148,149]. Zhang et al. [147] prepared CuCoAlO catalysts using LDH/metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) complexes as precursors (Fig. 12b). The prepared CuCoAlO catalysts demonstrated excellent low-temperature catalytic activity, as well as resistance to water and alkali metal poisoning. The catalysts achieved a NO conversion of 99.1% at 200 °C and maintained a NO removal efficiency of over 95% during long-term operation, exhibiting exceptional catalytic stability. In another study, Cu1.2FeMg2.8-LDO catalysts were obtained by roasting the CuFeMg-LDH precursor and showed excellent low-temperature catalytic activity and resistance to water and alkali metal poisoning, along with remarkable catalytic stability. The catalyst achieved 100% NO conversion across a wide temperature range of 225-600 °C. The researchers highlighted the strong synergistic interaction between Cu and Fe, which promoted the catalyst's redox capacity and the generation of surface reactive oxygen species, significantly enhancing the catalytic performance [150]. 4.1.2.2 Effects of the valence state of copper species The valence state of copper plays a crucial role in the catalytic activity of CO-SCR. Previous studies have suggested that copper species with low valence states (Cu+, Cu0) serve as active sites for excellent catalytic performance [151–153]. In recent years, it has been shown that the catalytic performance of copper can be significantly enhanced by modulating its valence state. In particular, zero-valent copper (Cu0) has been identified as a key factor in improving reaction performance. Yao et al. [154] used an in situ pretreatment technique to modulate the valence state of Cu species and found that the Cu0 species in the 06CuAl-R catalysts exhibited optimal activity and selectivity. Cu0 plays a key role in the dissociation of adsorbed NO by efficiently transferring electrons into the antibonding orbitals of the adsorbed NO, weakening the N-O bond and promoting NO dissociation, thereby significantly enhancing catalytic performance. Zhou et al. [34] successfully prepared three MOF-based catalysts—Cu/C, Cu-CuO/C, and CuO/C—each containing different valence states of Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+. The results showed that the Cu/C catalyst, which contained only Cu0 species, demonstrated the best activity and selectivity in the temperature range from 350°C to 500°C. In this range, Cu0 as the active center has a low activation energy and reaction energy barrier in the NO dissociation step, making the Cu/C catalyst more sensitive to the CO-SCR reaction. This study also indicated that Cu0 was the most effective active center for promoting NO dissociation (the key step in CO reduction of NO), followed by Cu+, and finally Cu2+. Similarly, Wang et al. [155] argued that Cu0 species were more favorable for NO dissociation at low temperatures, facilitating NO conversion. However, the aggregation and enlargement of Cu0 particles at higher temperatures resulted in a decrease in active sites, thus reducing NO conversion efficiency. On the other hand, some researchers have suggested that Cu+ species significantly enhance the low-temperature activity of catalysts due to their unique electronic structure and reactivity [130]. They proposed that CO-Cu+ interactions are stronger than CO-Cu2+ and CO-Cu0 interactions. The formation of Cu+ species after CO pretreatment of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts enhanced CO adsorption and activation at temperatures below 200°C, contributing to improve NO reduction efficiency [156]. Recently, the Cu-Ce bimetallic system has gained considerable attention for its excellent CO-SCR performance, with Cu+ species regarded as the main active species in the NO reduction reaction. The incorporation of CeO2 not only improves CuO species dispersion but also enhances the catalyst's redox performance, allowing for the formation of more low-oxidation-state metal species (Cu+) and surface oxygen vacancies (SOVs). These features effectively promote NO dissociation and N2 generation [32,143,157,158]. Liu et al. [159] prepared a series of Cu-Mn composite oxide catalysts and systematically investigated their performance in CO oxidation and CO-SCR reactions. The study found that Cu0.075Mn catalysts formed a Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 spinel structure with a predominance of Mn3+ and Cu2+, leading to more oxygen defects and chemisorbed oxygen species, which resulted in the highest catalytic activity for CO oxidation. The Cu0.15Mn catalyst exhibited the highest CO-SCR activity, achieving 100% NO conversion and near 100% N₂ selectivity at 275°C. This result suggests that Cu+ species, through synergistic interactions with Mn species, form surface synergistic oxygen vacancies (Cu+-□-Mnn+) that promote NO reduction in the CO-SCR reaction. Yamamoto et al. [134] found that highly dispersed Cu2+ species are key to catalytic activity. These Cu2+ species may facilitate NO reduction and CO oxidation through interactions with NO and CO, without being over-reduced to the metallic Cu0 state. Additionally, it was observed that Cu species are partially reduced to Cu+ under low O2 concentrations, which may be related to the redox cycle of the reaction. However, under high O2 concentrations, Cu species predominantly exist as Cu2+, suggesting that the valence stability of Cu species in aerobic conditions is crucial for catalyzing the reaction. Amano et al. [160] discovered that Cu oxides loaded on γ-Al2O3 exhibit unique one-electron reduction behavior in the presence of H2, where Cu2+ ions are reduced to Cu+ ions. This behavior promotes the CO reduction reaction of NO under oxygenated conditions, with the mechanism based on the redox cycling between Cu2+ and Cu+. Jin et al. [161] reported that Cu2+ in CuM2O4 spinel-type catalysts, with surface oxygen vacancies (Ov) in the Cu2+-Ov-Mδ+ sites, plays a key role in enhancing the CO-SCR performance of CuM2O4 catalysts. 4.1.2.3 Effect of auxiliary modification Introducing additives has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing the catalytic performance of catalysts. Cerium (Ce), with its two valence states (Ce4+ and Ce3+), undergoes rapid redox transitions between these states and CeO2 exhibits significant oxygen storage capacity and excellent redox properties. Zhang et al. [162] investigated the effect of cerium modification on the catalytic performance of Cu-BTC catalysts in the low-temperature CO-SCR. They found that the introduction of Ce increased the number of oxygen vacancies, which contributed to the adsorption and activation of NO. This modification also promoted the conversion of Cu2+ to Cu+, further enhancing the reduction ability of the catalyst. As a result, the Ce-Cu-BTC catalyst achieved 91% NO conversion at 250 °C, significantly higher than the unmodified Cu-BTC, which achieved only 50%. The doping of Ce also enhanced the dispersion of Cu species and increased the surface adsorbed oxygen content of the catalysts, thereby improving catalytic performance [163]. Previous studies reported that Ce-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3, prepared by the stepwise impregnation method, exhibited nearly 90% NO conversion at a reaction temperature of 325 °C [144]. Wang et al. [164] developed Mn-Cu-CeOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with dual active centers by introducing Mn. These catalysts exhibited excellent low-temperature activity, achieving NOx conversion of 98% and CO conversion of 96% at 200 °C. The strong interactions between Mn, Cu, and Ce oxides promoted their high dispersion on the γ-Al2O3 surface, resulting in smaller particle sizes. This optimization not only enhanced the low-temperature reduction performance of the catalyst but also increased the concentration of acidic sites, enhanced the migration of oxygen species, and improved the adsorption efficiency of NO and CO, significantly boosting its low-temperature catalytic activity. Manganese, with its multiple valence states, facilitates the transformation between Mn3+ and Mn4+, generating a large number of surface-active oxygen species. This unique catalytic redox property makes manganese a common choice for modifying catalysts to improve CO-SCR performance. Li et al. [165] demonstrated that the introduction of Mn promoted the redox reaction between Cu2+ and Mn3+, leading to the partial reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+. The Cu+ species, together with oxygen vacancies and Fe²⁺, formed the Cu+-Ov-Fe2+ active site, which exhibited superior low-temperature catalytic activity and resistance to alkali metal tolerance compared to the Cu2+-Ov-Fe2+ active site in CuFe2O4 catalysts. Shi et al. [166] reported that in a three-phase system of Mn-modified CuFe2O4, γ-Fe2O3, and CuO, the synergistic interaction of Mn4+ with the surfaces of these phases generated reactive oxygen species (e.g., Cu2+-O-Mn4+ and Mn4+-O-Fe3+). These species were more readily reduced to synergistic oxygen vacancies (SSOVs), facilitating NO dissociation and the transfer of oxygen species. Sun et al. [167] also demonstrated that different manganese precursors affected the formation of SSOVs, which in turn influenced the reaction performance of the catalyst. Researchers have also modified catalysts by introducing other metals to further enhance catalytic performance. Ding et al. [168] investigated the synergistic effect of nitrogen-coordinated bimetallic sites in the CO-SCR reaction. The CuFe-N/C catalysts, developed over a wide temperature range (225–400°C), achieved near 100% NO conversion and high N2 selectivity, outperforming single-metal catalysts. This was primarily due to the preferential adsorption of CO molecules by Cu-N sites and the stabilizing effect of Fe-N sites on ONNO intermediates. Additionally, the electron transfer mechanism between Cu and Fe (Fe → Cu → ONNO → Fe) facilitated efficient interfacial electron transfer, significantly improving catalytic activity. Pan et al. [169] developed a CuCoAl-LDO catalyst based on a two-dimensional hydrotalcite structure, achieving a high NO conversion of up to 96.6% at 150 °C. Al doping significantly increased the catalyst's specific surface area, exposing more active sites. The synergistic interaction between Cu and Co formed Cu+-□-Co3+ surface synergistic oxygen vacancies (SSOVs), promoting the redox cycling of Cu and Co and significantly improving low-temperature catalytic activity (Fig. 13a). Liu et al. [170] concluded that doping with La significantly reduced the particle size of Cu and Mn, preventing agglomeration, thus enhancing catalyst reducibility, increasing exposed active sites, and improving reactivity. The introduction of La3+ enhanced the Mn4++Cu+↔Mn3++Cu2+ redox cycle, generating numerous Cux+-□-La3+-□-Mny+ species (□ denotes surface synergistic oxygen vacancies (Fig. 13b). These synergistic nodes promoted NO dissociation and the transfer of free oxygen, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. 4.1.2.4 Effect of morphological structure The unique morphology of the catalyst contributes to a larger specific surface area, thereby providing more active sites. Tian et al. [171] treated a high-entropy oxide catalyst (CuCoMnFeNi) with alkali at a specific temperature, transforming the catalyst from large, irregular particles to an ultrathin lamellar structure with a thickness of only 3 nm, significantly smaller than the untreated CuCoMnFeNi (>20 nm). This ultrathin lamellar structure not only increases the specific surface area and exposes more active sites and oxygen vacancies but also promotes electron transfer between metal sites, optimizing the catalyst's electronic state and thereby enhancing its activity and selectivity in the CO-SCR reaction (Fig. 14a). Chen et al. [172] prepared a series of Cu/Co catalysts with different Cu/Co ratios using the CTAB-assisted hydrothermal method (Fig. 14b). Among them, Cu5 (Cu/Co ratio of 5:10) exhibited the best catalytic activity. The structural morphology of the catalysts significantly affected their performance, with Cu5 catalysts featuring a porous nanosheet structure, large specific surface area, and well-developed pore structure, which substantially enhanced catalytic activity. Qin et al. [173] investigated a distinctive peanut-shaped nanocavity structure in the Cu0.75Mn2.25O4 spinel catalyst for the low-temperature CO reduction of NO (Fig. 14c). More than 90% NO conversion was achieved at 200 °C with more than 80% N2 selectivity. This structure not only increased the catalyst’s specific surface area and pore volume but also promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies, enhancing redox performance and oxygen mobility. Three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) catalysts have a significant impact on the catalytic performance of CO-SCR due to their unique pore structure and large specific surface area. Liu et al. [174] reported that 3DOM CuFe2O4 spinel catalysts exhibited superior performance, with a high specific surface area and abundant surface reactive oxygen species, enhancing both CO oxidation and NO reduction activities.
