The strong synergistic interaction between Cu2+ and Fe3+ facilitated rapid electron transfer, improving the catalyst’s reduction performance, particularly at low temperatures. Their group also prepared 3DOM Ce0.7Fe0.2Cu0.1O2 catalysts with colloidal crystal templates, which exhibited high CO-SCR activity over a wide temperature range of 150-700 °C [175]. Compared with conventional Cu-modified Ce-Fe composite oxides, the 3DOM-structured catalysts had increased active site numbers and enhanced contact efficiency between reactants and catalysts due to their unique morphology (Fig. 14d). XPS, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy analyses revealed that the 3DOM catalysts possessed a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies and a greater number of surface-adsorbed oxygen species, properties that contributed to improved redox capacity and NOx adsorption and activation. Modulating the crystalline facets of the carrier optimizes the interaction between CuO and the carrier, thereby enhancing CO-SCR performance. Kang et al. [176] extensively investigated the effect of CeO2 carriers with different exposed crystalline facets on the performance of CuO/CeO2 catalysts in the low-temperature CO-SCR reaction. By designing the carriers with different exposed crystalline facets, they found that the CeO2 carrier with exposed (110) crystalline facets (CuO/CeO2-R) exhibited the best catalytic activity, achieving complete conversion of NO and CO at 250 °C. Characterization tools revealed that the interaction between the different crystalline surfaces of CeO2 and CuO modulated the interfacial structure and oxygen vacancy (Ov) content. The CuO/CeO2-R catalysts possessed the largest number of Cu+-Ov-Ce3+ interfacial active sites, which played a critical role in the reaction. Additionally, their abundant oxygen vacancies facilitated NO dissociation, significantly enhancing catalytic efficiency. In contrast, Liu et al. [41] controlled the exposed crystalline surface by altering the morphology of the carrier. They found that CeO2 nanorods, with exposed (110) and (100) crystalline surfaces, promoted CuO reduction and CeO2 surface oxygen migration more efficiently at low temperatures, leading to higher activity and better N2 selectivity. However, nano cubes exhibited lower activity and N2 selectivity due to the weaker interaction of the (100) crystalline facets on their surfaces with CuO. 4.1.2.5 Summary of influencing factors In conclusion, enhancing the low-temperature CO-SCR performance of copper-based catalysts is highly effective through optimizing preparation methods, modulating the valence state of copper species, doping with auxiliaries, and adjusting the catalyst morphology. Studies have shown that impregnation techniques (especially co-impregnation) and LDH precursor derivatization are promising strategies. Catalysts prepared by impregnation methods exhibit significant advantages in promoting CO adsorption and NO dissociation due to a high proportion of Cu+ species and abundant surface oxygen vacancies, which effectively enhance the catalytic efficiency of the CO-SCR reaction. For further enhancement of the catalyst's resistance to poisons, LDH derivatization is more suitable as it can significantly improve the stability and durability of the catalyst. The valence state of copper species has a profound impact on the catalytic performance of low-temperature CO-SCR reactions. Comprehensive analysis indicates that Cu+ is considered the most advantageous valence state due to its unique electronic structure and reactivity, as well as its ability to form synergistic interactions with oxygen vacancies, which promote the adsorption and dissociation of NO. However, under specific high-temperature or high-oxygen conditions, the synergistic interaction between Cu2+ and Cu+ is also crucial for significantly enhancing catalytic performance, highlighting the importance of rationally regulating the valence state of copper species under varying operating conditions. Future research should focus on significantly enhancing overall catalyst performance by optimizing preparation methods and carrier materials, and precisely regulating the content and distribution of Cu+ species. Regarding auxiliary modification, the rapid redox cycling between different valence states of Mn generates numerous surface-active oxygen species, significantly boosting the redox capacity and surface reactivity of the catalyst. There is also a notable synergistic effect between Mn4+ and surface Cu species, prone to generating synergistic oxygen vacancies (SSOV), thus promoting NO dissociation and oxygen species transfer. Therefore, Mn-modified copper-based catalysts show promise for CO-SCR reactions; however, it should be noted that Mn may reduce N2 selectivity under certain conditions due to its strong oxidizing properties. Future studies need to optimize the composition and structure of the catalysts to balance activity and selectivity while enhancing catalytic performance. Additionally, special morphological structures of the catalysts, such as ultrathin sheets, porous nanosheets, peanut-shaped nanocavities, and 3DOM structures, not only significantly increase the specific surface area and number of active sites but also promote the formation of oxygen vacancies and electron transfer between metal sites, enhancing the redox capacity and oxygen migration ability of the catalysts. Optimizing these morphological structures provides an important route to improving CO-SCR reaction efficiency. In future research, exploring how to optimize the surface chemistry and interfacial structure of catalysts by precisely modulating their morphology and crystalline surfaces will be a key direction to further improve CO-SCR reaction efficiency. 4.1.3 Effect of SO2 on catalytic activity The presence of SO2 in industrial flue gas leads to catalyst deactivation, significantly affecting catalytic performance. On one hand, SO2 molecules compete with key reactants (e.g., NO, CO) for active sites on the catalyst, inhibiting their chemisorption processes [177]. On the other hand, the sulfation of active components can block or destroy the active centers, thereby reducing the catalyst's performance [147]. Jiang et al. [178] investigated three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) Cu-Ce bimetallic composite oxide catalysts for CO-SCR and found that introducing 200 ppm SO2 into the reaction gas drastically reduced NO conversion from 99.2% to approximately 40%. This significant decline was primarily attributed to SO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, leading to the formation of sulfate and sulfite species that occupied active sites and inhibited NO adsorption and conversion. Similarly, Wang et al. [179] observed that introducing 200 ppm SO2 into the reaction gas decreased the CO-SCR efficiency of the Cu1Ce0.5Fe1.5O4.25 catalyst from 95% to 80%, while increasing N2O selectivity from ∼0.3 to 0.34. This phenomenon suggests that SO2 not only reduces NO conversion but also enhances N2O generation. Further analysis via SO2-temperature-programmed desorption (SO2-TPD) experiments revealed distinct sulfate and sulfite decomposition peaks at 890 °C and 680 °C, respectively, indicating that SO2 forms sulfate and sulfite species on the catalyst surface, leading to poisoning of the active sites. In recent years, to mitigate catalyst deactivation caused by SO2 in flue gas, scientists have explored various strategies. One approach involves enhancing the sulfur resistance of catalysts by inhibiting SO2 adsorption on their surfaces. For instance, Xu et al. [180] modified CeCuCoAlO catalysts by incorporating Ni, thereby improving their sulfur tolerance. Their study revealed that nickel modification effectively increased the proportion of high-valent cations (Cu2+ and Co3+), significantly suppressing SO2 adsorption at active sites and minimizing sulfate species formation. Additionally, nickel doping stabilized the concentration of chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) on the surface, enhancing the activation efficiency of reaction gases. These synergistic effects enabled the Ni0.15CeCuCoAlO catalyst to maintain a 90% NO conversion rate even at an SO2 concentration of 200 ppm, representing a twofold improvement over unmodified catalyst. Furthermore, modifying the catalyst's morphology can also inhibit SO2 adsorption, contributing to enhanced sulfur resistance [123,133]. Another strategy to enhance SO2 tolerance involves reducing the generation of sulfate species. Wang et al. [179] investigated the sulfur resistance of CeCu-FeOx catalysts and found that adjusting the Fe loading ratio could significantly suppress sulfate formation. Specifically, increasing the Fe content optimized the pore structure of the catalyst and promoted SO2 to exist in a chemisorbed state or as sulfite rather than stable sulfate, thus reducing its occupation of active sites. Moreover, the introduction of Fe inhibited the reaction between Cu species and SO2, protecting the highly active Cu sites from sulfur poisoning. Additional strategies such as inhibiting SO2 oxidation [181] and constructing sacrificial active sites [182] have also been employed to further improve sulfur resistance. These methods collectively aim to reduce the detrimental impact of SO2 on catalyst performance. Future research should focus on developing additional methods to enhance catalyst performance in complex real-world industrial environments. 4.2 NH3-SCR coupled with CO catalytic oxidation 4.2.1 Reaction mechanism In the NH3-SCR coupled with CO oxidation reaction, the involvement of two reactions and their interactions may lead to both favorable and unfavorable effects. Understanding the interactions between the reactants is crucial for developing more efficient bifunctional catalysts. 4.2.1.1 Effect of CO oxidation on NH3-SCR An in-depth investigation of the effect of the CO oxidation reaction on NH3-SCR is crucial for enhancing the efficiency of both reactions in removing pollutants together. However, the academic community has not yet reached a consensus on whether the catalytic oxidation of CO promotes or inhibits NOx reduction. Some researchers argue that the catalytic oxidation of CO may enhance NOx reduction efficiency. Zheng et al. [18] found that when CO was involved in the NH3-SCR reaction in Cu/Mn catalysts, the NO conversion increased by 66.1% at 125°C compared to the NH3-SCR reaction alone. Similarly, Guo et al. [183] observed that the introduction of CO promoted NO conversion, primarily because NO was adsorbed onto pre-adsorbed CO sites, where CO acted as a reductant to reduce NO to N2 via an alternative pathway. Recent studies have also shown that utilizing the heat released from CO oxidation enhances NO conversion and reduces energy consumption for NO reduction [3,19]. In contrast, other researchers suggest that CO presence inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction. Gui et al. [184] found that CO inhibited the NH3-SCR reaction, mainly due to the competing adsorption of NH3 and CO on the catalyst surface. Similarly, Xuan et al. [185] demonstrated that CO addition inhibited NH3-SCR activity at low temperatures, primarily because of the competitive adsorption of CO with NH3 on the catalyst surface, which altered the acid-base and redox properties of the catalyst. However, the involvement of CO significantly improved N2 selectivity, likely because N2O produced during the NH3-SCR reaction was further reduced to N2 through reaction with CO. 4.2.1.2 Effect of NH3-SCR on CO oxidation Similarly, the presence of NH3 in the same reaction system can also influence the catalytic oxidation of CO. Zheng et al. [18] found that the CO conversion in the synergistic reaction in a Cu/Mn catalyst increased by 40.6% at 125 °C compared to the CO oxidation reaction alone. This enhancement may be due to the formation of acidic sites on the catalyst surface by NH3, which facilitates the adsorption and activation of CO (Fig. 15a). Guo et al. [183] reported the formation of NO2 − and N2O2 − species on the catalyst surface in the presence of NO, which act as important intermediates that facilitate the catalytic oxidation of CO. Wang et al. [8] investigated the effect of α-MnO2 on α-MnO2-Cu catalysts in the NH3-SCR reaction and CO oxidation. Their findings, shown in Fig. 15b, indicated that the presence of NH3 inhibited CO oxidation, primarily because the pre-adsorbed NH3 reduced the formation of Mn-COO formate intermediates, thereby decreasing CO oxidation efficiency. In contrast, the introduction of NO facilitated CO oxidation, as gaseous CO formed intermediates with nitrate and nitrite species, which were subsequently decomposed into CO2, enhancing CO oxidation. When both NH3 and NO were present, the promoting effect of NO counteracted the inhibitory effect of NH3, maintaining the efficiency of the CO oxidation reaction. Wang et al. [164] found that MnCeOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited good NH3-SCR activity. However, the presence of NH3 inhibited the efficiency of CO catalytic oxidation due to competitive adsorption. This unfavorable effect was alleviated by introducing Cu as a modification, resulting in a dual-activity center catalyst. 4.2.2 Effecting factors of catalytic performance CO-SCR technology can simultaneously remove both CO and NOx emissions from coke oven flue gas. However, in practice, coke oven flue gas is typically in an oxygen-rich environment, which makes CO more prone to oxidation into carbon dioxide (CO2), significantly inhibiting the CO-SCR denitrification process [184]. To achieve efficient simultaneous removal of both NOx and CO, researchers have turned their attention to bifunctional catalysts that combine NH3-SCR with the catalytic oxidation of CO. These bifunctional catalysts can effectively perform NH3-SCR denitrification and CO catalytic oxidation within the same reaction system, thus addressing the inhibition of the denitrification reaction caused by CO under oxygen-rich conditions. Current research efforts are focused on improving the performance of these bifunctional catalysts. Copper-based catalysts have become a prominent area of study in this field due to their excellent activity in both NH3-SCR [186] and CO catalytic oxidation [73,187] reactions, as well as their abundant availability and low cost. 4.2.2.1 Effect of auxiliary modification The modification of catalysts by additives helps balance their redox properties and surface acidity, which enhances the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules, thereby improving catalytic activity [188]. Lv et al. [189] modified Cu/TiO2 catalysts by introducing Sm, leading to the formation of asymmetric active sites (Cu+-Sm3+-Ov-Ti4+) that significantly enhance catalytic performance. The modified catalyst achieved complete NO conversion at 200°C, with no by-products detected throughout the reaction, outperforming the unmodified Cu/TiO2 catalyst. This superior performance can be attributed to several factors: (1) the formation of asymmetric active sites promotes the increase of Cu+ species and oxygen vacancy enrichment, which accelerates the redox cycle and aids in CO adsorption; (2) the highly dispersed Cu species on the catalyst surface enhance reduction performance; and (3) the abundance of Lewis acid sites facilitates the adsorption and activation of reactants (Fig. 16a). Liu et al. [190] significantly improved the catalytic performance of CuCeZr catalysts at medium to high temperatures (250–350°C) by introducing P. As shown in Fig. 16b, the P modification played a crucial role in balancing the catalyst’s redox capacity and surface acidity, helping to inhibit the over-oxidation of NH3 and significantly enhancing the reduction reaction's activity and N2 selectivity, despite negatively affecting CO oxidation activity at low temperatures. Furthermore, P introduction inhibited the accumulation of inert nitrate species, promoting the NH3-SCR reaction through the E-R mechanism. Zang et al. [191] compared the catalytic performances of CuMgFeO, CuFeO, and MgFeO, noting that the interactions among the three metals in CuMgFeO catalysts led to more than 85% NOx and CO conversion in the 200–300°C range (Fig. 16c). This excellent performance was primarily due to the good dispersion of CuO species, high redox capacity, and abundant acidic sites. Shen et al. [192] investigated Mo-modified CuCeOx catalysts for the simultaneous removal of NOx and CO. The modified catalysts exhibited highly dispersed active components, strong redox capacity, and abundant acidic sites, enhancing their low-temperature activity. Li et al. [193] and Wu et al. [194] studied the effect of Fe modification on Cu/TiO2 catalysts for simultaneous NO and CO removal, and found that the modification significantly improved catalytic performance. This enhancement was attributed to superior redox capacity, an abundance of medium strength acid sites, and the formation of a large number of oxygen vacancies. Bifunctional catalysts face competition between two reactants for adsorption, which can inhibit catalyst activity. Therefore, measures must be taken to reduce this competing adsorption, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance of bifunctional catalysts. Wang et al. [164] modified catalysts by introducing Mn, preparing MnCuCeOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with dual active centers, and investigating their performance as bifunctional catalysts. When compared with MnCeOx/γ-Al2O3 and CuCeOx/γ-Al2O3, it was found that MnCeOx/γ-Al2O3 performed well in the NH3-SCR reaction, while CuCeOx/γ-Al2O3 was more effective in CO-catalyzed oxidation, with each catalyst performing poorly in the other reaction. The dual-activity MnCuCeOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, containing both MnCe and CuCe species, provided both NH3-SCR activity centers and CO catalytic oxidation activity centers, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic performance. Similarly, Gui et al. [184] prepared Mn2Cu1Al1Ox catalysts with dual-activity centers, which exhibited superior performance with 86.8% NOx conversion and 100% CO conversion at 200°C, outperforming the single-active-center Mn3Al1Ox and Cu3Al1Ox catalysts. For single-active-center catalysts, MnOx was highly effective for the NH3-SCR reaction, while CuOx was more advantageous for CO oxidation, due to competitive adsorption between NH3 and CO, which inhibited catalytic activity. In contrast, the dual-active-center Mn2Cu1Al1Ox catalysts benefited from a synergistic effect: NH3 was preferentially adsorbed on the Mn active sites, while CO was more readily adsorbed on the Cu active sites, promoting the simultaneous NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation reactions (Fig. 16d). Additionally, Zeng et al. [195] reported that the introduction of Ti species induced the formation of CuO/CeO2 catalysts with a three-dimensional pore structure, promoting a phase transition from crystalline to amorphous states. This significantly improved the specific surface area and dispersion of active species. The well-dispersed CuO and CeO2 species provided more adsorption sites for CO and NO, enhancing Cu-Ce interactions and the formation of additional oxygen vacancies. These factors reduced the competing adsorption between CO and NO, facilitating the simultaneous removal of NOx and CO by the Ti-modified CuO/CeO2 bifunctional catalyst. 4.2.2.2 Effect of metal ratio The NOx and CO removal efficiencies of catalysts at low temperatures can be significantly enhanced by precisely modulating the ratio of active components. Gui et al. [184] investigated dual-active center Mn2Cu1Al1Ox catalysts and found that MnOx excelled in NH3-SCR reactions, while CuOx was more effective in CO oxidation reactions. By adjusting the Cu/Mn ratio, the researchers successfully optimized the catalyst for the best performance. As shown in Fig. 17a and Fig. 17b, with an increase in Mn and Cu content, the overall NOx and CO conversion rates increased. Considering both NOx and CO conversions together, the catalyst with the Mn2Cu1Al1Ox ratio exhibited the most outstanding performance, efficiently removing both NOx and CO at low temperatures (180-220 °C). Shen et al. [196] also thoroughly examined the effect of the Cu-to-Mo ratio on catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 17a and Fig. 17b, the conversion of NOx and CO increased with the Cu/Mo ratio in the range of 0.1–0.3. However, the removal efficiency of both pollutants in the CCM7 catalyst was lower than that of the CC catalyst without Mo modification, suggesting that excessive Mo doping hindered the removal of NOx and CO. Xuan et al. [197] highlighted the crucial role of the Cu-to-Mn ratio in catalytic performance. The catalyst CM-3, with a Cu-to-Mn molar ratio of 1:3, achieved 100% NOx and CO conversion at 175 °C. Increasing Mn content further improved low-temperature activity to some extent, but excessive Mn resulted in a catalyst surface structure that was unfavorable for the NH3 + NO reaction, reducing NOx conversion. An optimal Cu/Mn ratio promotes solid solution formation and improves coordination between the metals, enhancing the catalyst's low-temperature performance. Li et al. [198] investigated the effects of WO3 and CuO loading on catalyst activity. They found that the addition of WO3 enhanced the surface acidity, facilitating the NH3-SCR reaction, though it reduced redox performance to some extent. The introduction of CuO significantly boosted redox capacity and improved CO conversion efficiency. However, excessive CuO loading led to particle aggregation on the catalyst surface, inhibiting catalytic activity at low temperatures. Therefore, the loading amounts of WO3 and CuO must be carefully optimized. In summary, the 5Cu-10W-CZ catalyst demonstrated the most outstanding catalytic activity, thanks to the high dispersion of active components, excellent redox properties, and strong surface acidity. 4.2.2.3 Effects of other factors The carrier plays a crucial role in the conversion and selectivity of bifunctional catalysts. Previous studies have shown that the Cu1Mn2 catalyst achieved 100% NO conversion and 96.4% CO conversion at 125 °C due to its high Cu doping; however, the N2 selectivity remained suboptimal, leaving room for improvement [18]. To address this, Yang et al. [183] optimized the CuMn catalyst by preparing a CuMn-HZSM-5 hybrid catalyst. This modification maintained excellent low-temperature NO and CO conversions while ensuring that N2 selectivity remained above 90% in the range of 175–275 °C. This improvement is attributed to the reduced number of Lewis acid sites on the carrier after loading the CuMn active component, as well as the decreased reducibility of the CuMn-HZSM-5 catalyst. The effect between the two components mitigated the non-selective oxidation of NH3, thus enhancing N2 selectivity. Jia et al. [3] loaded CuMnFe composite metal oxides onto TiO2 nanotubes to further enhance N2 selectivity. The incorporation of titanium nanotubes decreased the mobility of adsorbed oxygen and reduced the catalyst's reducibility, thus minimizing the non-selective oxidation of NH3 by-products. Ren et al. [199] compared the effects of different crystal structures of MnO2 as a carrier on catalytic performance. The catalytic performance was ranked as CuOx/α-MnO2 > CuOx/γ-MnO2 > CuOx/δ-MnO2 > CuOx/β-MnO2. The CuOx/α-MnO2 catalyst exhibited the highest ratio of Cu+ and Mn4+, the largest number of total acid centers, and the richest surface adsorbed oxygen, making it the most efficient for the simultaneous removal of NO and CO. Additionally, Cu can be used as an additive in Mn-based and Ce-based catalysts to improve the performance of catalysts for simultaneous NO and CO removal. Li et al. [7] demonstrated that Cu could modify CeFe catalysts to enhance their activity for simultaneous NO and CO removal. CuO modification optimized the acidity and redox capacity of the catalyst surface, reaching a balanced state that enhanced the adsorption and activation of reactive gases. The Cu-CeFe catalysts were rich in oxygen vacancies, generating a large amount of Ce3+ and Oβ, which facilitated the selective reduction of NO and the catalytic oxidation of CO. Zeng et al. [19] reported that CuO modification significantly improved the catalytic performance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts, with NOx and CO conversions exceeding 90% in the range of 225–270 °C. The addition of CuO not only provided active sites for CO oxidation but also promoted the adsorption and activation of NH3. Furthermore, the synergistic interaction between CuO and VOx enhanced catalyst activity through the newly formed Cu+ + V5+ ↔ Cu2+ + V5+ redox cycle. Wang et al. [8] reported that the incorporation of Cu species into α-MnO2-Cu nanorod catalysts significantly enhanced several critical properties, including redox capacity, oxygen storage capacity, the number of acidic sites on the surface, and the total amount of CO adsorption. These enhancements collectively contributed to an increase in the overall catalytic activity. 4.2.2.4 Summary of influencing factors In summary, the performance of NH3-SCR coupled with CO oxidation bifunctional catalysts can be significantly enhanced by introducing additives such as Sm, P, Fe, Mo, Mn, and Ce. Among these additives, modification of Cu-based catalysts with Mn shows particular promise. In the NH3-SCR coupled with CO oxidation reaction, competitive adsorption between the two reactant gases on the catalyst surface may inhibit catalytic activity. Mn-modified Cu-based catalysts effectively address this issue by forming dual active sites: Mn species provide specific sites for NH3 adsorption, while Cu species are more favorable for CO adsorption. This reduces competitive adsorption between the gases and significantly improves overall catalyst performance. Moreover, Mn-modified catalysts exhibit notable activity enhancements under low-temperature conditions, making them particularly valuable for applications in such environments. While the benefits of Mn modification are clear, it is also important not to overlook the potential of other additives. The performance of NH3-SCR coupled with CO oxidation bifunctional catalysts can be further improved by carefully selecting and optimizing the types of additives and their doping ratios. However, when doping additives for modification, the ratio of additives to Cu species must be precisely controlled. Lower ratios of metal doping may fail to achieve the desired modification effect, whereas excessively high ratios may lead to the aggregation of active components, thereby reducing low-temperature performance. Therefore, when designing modification strategies, it is crucial to optimize the dispersion of active species by precisely regulating the doping ratio of additives. This promotes a balance between the redox and acidic properties of the catalysts, thus comprehensively enhancing reaction efficiency. This deactivation primarily includes reversible and irreversible processes. Adsorbed SO2 reacts with active components to form sulfate species that occupy active sites on the catalyst surface and block pores, resulting in a decrease in the specific surface area. These stable sulfates cannot be decomposed under high-temperature calcination, leading to irreversible deactivation [201]. Reversible deactivation can be divided into two primary cases. In one scenario, competitive adsorption occurs between SO2 and reactant molecules. Catalyst activity can be restored through washing or acid washing at low temperatures [202]. In another case, under aerobic conditions, SO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface is oxidized to SO3, which then reacts with NH3 to produce (NH4)2SO4/NH4HSO4, depositing these substances on the catalyst surface [203]. For example, Szanyi et al. [204] demonstrated that SO2 primarily inhibits CuO/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts by forming sulfates mainly at the CuO-CeO2-ZrO2 interface. This formation significantly reduces oxygen mobility and the amount of oxygen involved in reactions on the catalyst surface, while also weakening the adsorption strength of CO at Cu+ sites through electronic effects. Yang et al. [205] further showed that the introduction of SO2 leads to the formation of surface sulfates on the catalyst, covering active sites and hindering the CO oxidation reaction. This results in an irreversible decrease in conversion efficiency for the MnCu-YH catalyst, dropping to 0% after exposure to 50 ppm SO2. Zeng et al. [19] investigated CuO-modified V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts in the synergistic reaction of NH3-SCR and CO oxidation. They found that SO2 preferentially reacts with CuO active sites to form CuSO4 and simultaneously with NH3 to form ammonium bisulfate, both of which cover active sites and clog catalyst pores. Furthermore, the generation of sulfates disrupts the Cu+/Cu2+ redox cycle with V5+/V4+, leading to complete loss of CO oxidation activity and partial reduction of NH3-SCR activity. Yan et al. [206] explored the impact of 100 ppm SO2 on the catalytic performance of various catalysts. The results indicated that Mn/TiO2 catalysts exhibit poor sulfur resistance, with NOx conversion efficiency dropping dramatically from 80.7% to 41.5% after 12 h of operation at 200°C. In contrast, Cu-Mn/TiO2 catalysts showed slightly better sulfur resistance, but NOx conversion efficiency still decreased significantly from 86.1% to 52.3% after prolonged operation. Notably, the Cu1Mn0.5Ti0.5Ox catalyst, prepared using layered double hydroxide as a precursor, exhibited excellent sulfur resistance. Its NOx conversion efficiency only dropped from 90% to 71.1% after 12 h of operation at 200°C, and under coexistence of 5% H2O and 100 ppm SO2, the catalyst maintained a NOx conversion efficiency of 64.6%, significantly higher than the other two catalysts. This indicates that the Cu1Mn0.5Ti0.5Ox catalyst possesses superior stability and activity in SO2-containing environments. To enhance sulfur resistance, introducing additional active components or optimizing preparation methods can be effective strategies. Increasing the surface acidity of the catalyst or designing structures that reduce SO2 adsorption, minimize SO2 oxidation, and construct sacrificial sites to protect more active sites can also mitigate the adverse effects of SO2 on the reaction. 5 Summary and outlook This paper reviews the research progress of copper-based catalysts for NOx and CO removal, focusing on their catalytic performance, reaction mechanisms, and the key factors influencing their performance in different reactions. Copper-based catalysts demonstrate high low-temperature activity and good thermal stability in both SCR and CO catalytic oxidation reactions, attributed to their excellent redox capacity and acidic properties. However, its practical application still faces some challenges, including poor N2 selectivity and poor dispersion of Cu active sites. To address the aforementioned challenges and further enhance the low-temperature activity of copper-based catalysts, this paper summarizes a variety of effective modification strategies. First, enhancing N2 selectivity can be achieved by modulating the valence distribution of copper species and introducing additives (e.g., Ce, Zr) to optimize the catalyst's surface chemistry. Second, improving the structural morphology of the catalysts to increase the exposure of active sites is another key approach to boosting catalytic performance. Additionally, optimizing preparation methods such as co-precipitation, sol-gel, or impregnation can significantly improve the dispersion and specific surface area of the catalysts, further enhancing their catalytic efficiency. Looking ahead, the development of copper-based catalysts should focus on several key areas: first, optimizing preparation processes and developing advanced synthesis methods to achieve high dispersion and homogeneous distribution of copper species; second, modulating catalyst morphology to improve catalytic performance by altering the pore structure, specific surface area, and surface oxygen vacancies; and third, exploring the doping effects of different metal oxides or nanomaterials to enhance multifunctionality and stability. In the field of coupled reactions, the combination of NH3-SCR and CO catalytic oxidation presents an innovative approach for the simultaneous removal of NOx and CO. By optimizing the redox properties and surface acidity of the catalysts, bifunctional catalysts can efficiently remove both pollutants in the same reaction system. However, the challenge of competitive adsorption between reactants still needs further resolution. Future studies should integrate advanced theoretical calculations (e.g., density-functional theory, DFT) and experimental characterization tools (e.g., in situ infrared spectroscopy, X-ray absorption fine-structure analysis) along with reaction kinetics studies to gain a deeper understanding of reaction pathways and the formation mechanisms of key intermediates. This approach will not only help elucidate the mechanisms of copper-based catalysts in the synergistic treatment of multi-pollutants but also provide an important theoretical foundation for designing efficient bifunctional catalysts. In summary, although copper-based catalysts still require improvements in terms of selectivity, catalytic activity, and co-catalytic mechanisms, they show great potential for NOx and CO removal. Future research will drive the development of copper-based catalysts toward higher efficiency and cost-effectiveness, offering more reliable solutions for air pollution control and making significant contributions to the achievement of sustainable development goals. coredata.dc:description: With the rapid acceleration of industrialization, the emission of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon monoxide (CO) has emerged as a pressing global environmental issue, posing significant threats to ecosystems and human health. Copper-based catalysts have garnered substantial attention in the field of multi-pollutant synergistic treatment due to their abundant availability, low cost, and superior catalytic performance. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the recent advancements in copper-based catalysts for the removal of NOx and CO from flue gas, with a focus on their applications in selective catalytic reduction (SCR), CO catalytic oxidation, and bifunctional co-catalysis. Through an in-depth analysis of key factors influencing catalytic performance—such as valence modulation, morphological structure design, optimization of preparation methods, auxiliary doping, and adjustment of metal ratios—the critical roles of various catalyst properties are elucidated. These include redox capabilities, acidic nature, surface oxygen vacancy concentration, and active site dispersion in the catalytic process. Furthermore, this paper explores in detail the reaction mechanisms and sulfur-resistant properties of copper-based catalysts employed in several strategies for NOx and CO removal, highlighting the potential of bifunctional catalysts for simultaneous NOx and CO abatement. Significant progress has been achieved in enhancing low-temperature activity and stability through the optimization of preparation processes, intermetallic interactions, and structural design of copper-based catalysts. These advancements provide crucial theoretical insights and practical guidance for the development of future environmental treatment technologies, paving the way for more efficient and sustainable solutions to address global pollution challenges.
